Award.AwardTitle: MRI Consortium: Acquisition of a Single Crystal X-Ray Diffractometer for Research and Pedagogy at Primarily Undergraduate Institutions
Award.AbstractNarration:
With this award from the Major Research Instrumentation Program that is co-funded by the Chemistry Research Instrumentation and Facilities (CRIF) Program, Professor Christopher Bradley from Mount St Mary's University and colleagues Daesung Chong (Ball State University), Tomothy Brunker (Towson University), Peter Craig (McDaniel College) and Timothy Funk (Gettysburg College) will acquire a single crystal X-ray diffractometer for use by a consortium of primarily undergraduate institutions that include Mount St Mary's University, Ball State University, Towson University, McDaniel College, Gettysburg College and Loyola University Maryland. The award is aimed at enhancing research and education at all levels, especially in areas such as (a) arene effects on cobalt catalysts for activated alkane dehydrogenation; (b) redox-induced linkage isomerism in chiral ruthenium sulfoxide complexes; (c) investigation of the stabilization of boron-containing cations by azametallocenes; (d) studies of model enzyme complexes; (e) coordination chemistry studies; (f) development of transition metal catalysts for organic transformations; (g) synthesis, reactivity, and crystallographic characterization of transition metal carbonyl complexes containing oxygen-donating ligands; and (h) catalysts for proton reduction.

An X-ray diffractometer allows accurate and precise measurements of the full three-dimensional structure of a molecule, including bond distances and angles, and provides accurate information about the spatial arrangement of a molecule relative to neighboring molecules. The studies described here will impact a number of areas, including organic and inorganic chemistry, materials chemistry and biochemistry. This instrument will be an integral part of teaching as well as research and research training not only at Mount St Mary's University but also at the neighboring institutions included in the consortium.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The project permitted acquisition of an X-ray diffractometer and creation of a common use X-ray diffraction facility among a consortium of five primarily undergraduate institutions (PUIs), representing colleges and universities in Indiana, Maryland, and Pennsylvania. The X-ray diffractometer provides undergraduates with access to state-of-the-art research equipment typically encountered only in graduate school. The facility also offers other PUIs outside the consortium the ability to access the diffractometer remotely for their own research needs. 

     The diffractometer is a powerful tool for structure determination of small molecules, with applications to a variety of disciplines, ranging from materials science to new pharmaceutical development to catalyst design for industrially relevant reactions.

     The instrument has enhanced both research and education efforts at the participating universities. With regard to research, the diffractometer has been integral in fully characterizing organic and inorganic compounds that have implications for the development of 1) more environmentally sustainable cobalt catalysts, 2) new metalloenzyme mimics with potential use in the treatment of antiobiotic resistant bacteria, and 3) chiral inorganic compounds for use in asymmetric synthesis of valuable organic molecules. In some cases, the diffractometer provides the primary means of characterization, which has transformed the ability to explore new research areas amongst consortium members. The instrument has provided data used in peer reviewed publications as well as national and international presentations by undergraduate research students and Co-PIs during the project. The diffractometer will continue to be a critical characterization method central to research conducted at all participating institutions.

     The diffractometer has also enhanced educational efforts at our institutions, by providing direct access to an advanced characterization technique in upper division lab courses. This has resulted in development of new courses in X-ray crystallography as well as integration of the instrument into many existing lab classes. The diffractometer has even been incorporated into outreach activities for high school students participating in summer research activities on our campuses.

     Exposure to the diffractometer has impacted the research experiences and career paths of our undergraduates, as many have decided to continue graduate studies in chemistry in disciplines which rely heavily on X-ray crystallography as a vital identification tool.   

     Collectively, the project has accomplished its research and educational goals while enhancing collaboration amongst the participating institutions of the consortium.
